text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer from English 
with Jennifer. Are you ready to work on

oral reading fluency? The text I wrote for 
you is short enough to read a few times.

Follow my lead, and I'll help you read 
clearly, naturally, and with expression.

Recent events in the news have once again 
made me think about why we pay so much

attention to famous people. They certainly 
pay a price for their fame. Is it worth it?

Only they can answer that question. By the way, I 
have another reading on this topic. If you'd like,

you can go back to practice text #4. 
That reading is shorter and easier.

All of my practice texts use high frequency 
words -- the words that are most commonly

used in English. But in this lesson, 
I increased the level of difficulty.

Before we read, let's study some 
vocabulary. When you learn a word,

it's helpful to become familiar with the whole 
word family. For example, if you learn a noun,

is there also a verb and an adjective? Let's 
see if you can recall different word forms.

If you're popular, what do you enjoy? 
What's the noun? It ends in -ity.
popularity - popularity - popularity

If you're rich, what do you 
enjoy? What's the plural noun?
riches

If you want a report to be full of details, what 
kind of report do you want? What's the adjective?
It ends in -ed.
Detailed. You want a detailed report.

When you play a game, you want the game to be 
fair. You want everyone to play by the rules,
so how do you want to play?
What's the adverb?
A lot of adverbs end in -ly.
fairly

If you have sympathy, you understand people's 
pain, so what kind of person are you?
What's the adjective?
A common adjective ending is -ic.
sympathetic - sympathetic - sympathetic

If you're a private person, you don't 
like to share a lot about yourself
with others, so what do you value?
What's the noun?
It ends in -cy.
privacy - privacy - privacy
If something is made of gold, it's very valuable.

Right? We can make an adjective from this word 
by adding -en. So, what's the new word? Golden.

"Golden" can mean "valuable" or "special," 
like a golden opportunity. In the reading,

I talk about a golden club. I'm referring 
to a special group of highly popular people.

Sometimes you may know one word, and 
it can help you recognize another.
Do you know the word "variety?" Variety.

It's a noun. Does it mean a lot of the 
same things or a lot of different things?

Different. So, now guess what I mean 
when I talk about various performers.

Different kinds of performers. "Various" is 
the adjective. When you see or hear a new word,

pay attention to how it's used. Often you 
can learn common phrases, set phrases.

We call them collocations. In 
the reading, you'll see these:
gain fame, in exchange for, pay a price,
front row seats,
a detailed account,

thick skin. If you have thick 
skin, then you don't let things,

especially other people's words, hurt you 
easily. The opposite of thick skin is thin skin.

Ups and downs. This can refer to success 
and failure. Fall short. If someone falls

short of something, then they almost 
reach their goal, but then they fail.

I have just three more words 
to show you. The first:

applaud. At the end of a good 
performance, we applaud. What do we do?
We all clap.

So-called. A so-called friend 
who lies isn't really a friend.

Right? We use "so-called" before another word 
when that really isn't the right word to use.

And the last one: severe. Severe weather like a 
tornado causes damage. So, what are severe words?
Are they kind or harsh?
Harsh.

If there are other words or expressions 
in the reading that are unfamiliar,

do your best to guess from context. 
We've covered enough vocabulary that

I think you'll understand the 
text quite well. Let's read.
First reading. Listen and read along silently.

"The Fame Game" Do you know about the fame 
game? We all do. A person can gain fame,

but they usually pay a price. They lose 
privacy in exchange for popularity and riches.

Few people make it into the golden club -- 
singers, actors, and various other performers.

Once they're in, they're sort of like 
gods. We admire them, follow them,

and learn all we can about them. But we're more 
than curious. We demand front row seats to watch

their so-called private lives. We welcome 
detailed accounts of their ups and downs.

Do we treat the famous 
fairly? We applaud their wins,

yet we're always ready to make severe remarks 
when they fall short of our moral standards.

What is it really like to be famous? One 
probably needs a lot of charm and very thick

skin to handle fame. Should 
we be more sympathetic or not?

Second reading. Listen and repeat. 
Follow my stress and intonation.
Do you know about the fame game?
We all do.
A person can gain fame,
but they usually pay a price.

They lose privacy in exchange 
for popularity and riches.
Few people make it into the golden club --
singers, actors, and various other performers.
Once they're in, they're sort of like gods.

We admire them, follow them, 
and learn all we can about
them. But we're more than curious.

We demand front row seats to watch 
their so-called private lives.

We welcome detailed accounts 
of their ups and downs.
Do we treat the famous fairly?
We applaud their wins,
yet we're always ready to make severe remarks
when they fall short of our moral standards.
What is it really like to be famous?

One probably needs a lot of charm 
and very thick skin to handle fame.
Should we be more sympathetic or not?

Third reading. Let's read together. We'll aim to 
read slowly and smoothly by linking our words.

Do you know about the fame game? 
We all do. A person can gain fame,

but they usually pay a price. They lose privacy 
in exchange for popularity and riches. Few people

make it into the golden club -- singers, actors, 
and various other performers. Once they're in,

they're sort of like gods. We admire them, 
follow them, and learn all we can about them.

But we're more than curious. We demand front row 
seats to watch their so-called private lives.

We welcome detailed accounts of their 
ups and downs. Do we treat the famous

fairly? We applaud their wins, yet we're 
always ready to make severe remarks

when they fall short of our moral standards. What 
is it really like to be famous? One probably needs

a lot of charm and very thick skin to handle 
fame. Should we be more sympathetic or not?

Fourth and final reading. 
Let's read together again.

We'll read at a natural pace. 
Aim to read with expression.

"The Fame Game" Do you know about the fame 
game? We all do. A person can gain fame,

but they usually pay a price. They lose privacy 
in exchange for popularity and riches. Few people

make it into the golden club -- singers, actors, 
and various other performers. Once they're in,

they're sort of like gods. We admire them, 
follow them, and learn all we can about them,

but we're more than curious. We 
demand front row seats to watch

their so-called private lives. We welcome 
detailed accounts of their ups and downs.

Do we treat the famous 
fairly? We applaud their wins,

yet we're always ready to make severe remarks 
when they fall short of our moral standards.

What is it really like to be famous? 
One probably needs a lot of charm

and very thick skin to handle fame. 
Should we be more sympathetic or not?

So, what do you think? Are we too severe when 
we form our opinions about famous people?

Should we be more sympathetic? You can 
let me know your thoughts in the comments.

Remember to practice. Continue listening 
and reading aloud. Follow my model. Record

yourself on Day One. Practice for a week, 
and then record yourself again on Day Seven.

Do you hear progress? Do you feel more 
confident? I hope so. That's all for now.

Please remember to like and share the 
video if you found the lesson useful.

As always, thanks for watching and happy 
studies! Follow me on Facebook, Twitter

and Instagram. Why not join me on Patreon? 
And don't forget to subscribe on YouTube.
